content.description: Great route for the new sport climbing leader.  Offers safe climbing on generous holds.  A somewhat committing, short crux section mid route.  Due to the prominent edge apprx. 8' below shuts, it is recommended to rappel from the shuts after finishing or bring a second up from the top to clean draws, then walk off to the left.
content.location: Just right of the tall main section of the left wall.  Obvious moderate bolted line.

content.description: First starting moves could be considered a crux and stick clipping might be a good option. Easier climbing from bolt 1 to 2.  Sustained climbing to be found above.
content.location: Off the large ledge of the right cliff.  Begins just left of the right end of ledge.

content.description: Short trad line with very good protection.  Follows inside corner to a crux top out involving some stemming.  Good climb for the grade.  Takes solid cams all the way.
content.protection: Light rack of small to medium cams.  Very solid rock.  Top out at trees and rap or walk off.
content.location: Climb follows short inside corner between the bolted climbs of Whale Tail 5.4 and Itchy Algae 5.10+. Walk off on descent trail to the left or rappel from tree rap station above Itchy Algae to the right.

content.description: From the small ledge, juggle your way up the arete to a stance under a small roof (crux). Follow the bolts to a big ledge under the prominent roof. Pull the roof, and anchors are just above that.
content.location: On the left wall (capped by a roof) of RE crag. Start beneath a small ledge just (very slightly) to the left of the arete.

content.description: One of the longer lines at River's End crag.  Small overhangs lead past the petrified tree the route is named after.  Crux is near top on short head wall at 5th bolt.
content.location: Located just right of where the approach trail from the bike trail meets the cliff.

content.description: Short and pumpy climb.  Thin crimps and seams up a slightly overhanging wall.  From the small ledge its fairly continuous and finishes on precarious moves at the top  Can be easily climbed via top rope after lowering from Carl's Bunnies the 5.9 arête to the right.
content.protection: Top rope anchor.  Climb is directly below the rap/lower anchor located on the bent tree directly above this route.  This rap anchor is for Carl's Bunnies 5.9 the arête to the right.
content.location: On the short face just left of the centrally located cliff breakdown between the right and left walls. Easier described as (right end of left wall).

content.description: Quality line of SWPA gritstone.  A short but very fun route.  Worth getting on despite its short nature.  Several committing moves put you at the tricky top out.  Commit to the finishing move and success is yours.  Highly recommend.  One of the best 3 bolt routes in SWPA.
content.protection: 3 bolts, lower from rap anchor at tree above. This anchor is shared with "Itchy Algae" 5.10+
content.location: Bolted route just left of breakdown between left and right cliffs at River's End.  Lower from rap station above "Itchy Algae"

content.description: Very fun climbing on flakes, crimps and a jug here and there.  Start can be damp several days after a rain.  The start is a little less than picturesque, but quickly turns quality.  The crux is up high on the route after the burn sets in.  Overhangs more than it looks.  Cool looking cobble rock!
content.location: Left end of right cliff.  First bolted climb coming down from the center of the two walls.

content.description: Start below the large shelf that splits the wall.  Climb the shorter section up to the shelf passing 2 bolts, from the shelf move up to the bulge (crux) pull the crux and finish on laybacks to the top.
content.protection: 5 bolts, Ring Shuts (optional gear placments possible).
content.location: On right wall.  Starts below large shelf on the ground.

content.description: One of the several downstream climbing areas on the Ohiopyle bike path (Great Allegheny Passage) in Ohiopyle State Park.  This crag consists of two separate walls with a short break down between.  Unlike many of the overhanging routes at nearby Schoolhouse and Maple Wall, Rivers End offers a higher concentration of bolted face climbs.  The left wall is easily recognized by a prominent roof and some overlaps.  The right side is vertical face climbing with few overhangs.  It gets full sun in the fall and winter which makes this a great spot on warm winter days.  In the summer there is plenty of shade to stay cool.  A great pit stop on the way to popular School House Crag (don't be surprised when you end up spending the whole day here).
